COLLEGE MEN IN BUSINESS.

cw

HILE it may seem presumptious for younger men to offer opinions about
a subject so much discussed by our elders, the suggestion prompts itself that the college graduate who has been in business only a few years
will be more respected as a judge, when it is remembered that he is closer to the
two conditions of life, and is more susceptible.
As a brief prelude, a few words about the length of an ideal college course
seem applicable. The many advocates of college training for men tell that this
incipient period of life is most in need of scientific care, for it is the chrystalizing stage,—a time when the hardening cast must be taken from the mould. Entering into business means undertaking a life pursuit, and a decision cannot be
summarily dismissed. While it is true that most men commencing business
are not permitted by circumstances to choose their exact branch, it must be admitted that a man who knows his own propensities, can by dint of determination fulfill his ambition at a later time. So that without venturing an opinion
as to the exact number of years to be spent in college, it is safe to say that the
cast must be formed, and tempered to the atmosphere before being exposed to
the elements.
.
Aside from the general polish and completeness that a college course gives
to all, the most refreshing observance that one makes of college men in business
IS the seriousness with which they view their life occupation. In the classes
of undergraduate years, in the self imposed work on college periodicals and in
athletics, it has been discovered that system and responsibility are essential to
all successes, and the ones who attain proficiency, or even mediocrity in any of
the college associations necessarily absorb most of the serious and solid elements of life.
The time taken up, and the exaggerated value that bachelors of art are apt
to set upon themselves, are the chief arguments advanced against a college degree for business men. In most cases, however, the time lost means only a
temporary delay, and the first objection seems very easily overcome. Of course,
there are many positions from which promotion can only be had in routine
order. In answer to this, it must be said that college men are brain-workers
and not machines, and that wherever there is a chance to excel and to be
recognized, the college man will receive and accept business principles as such.
He knows that discrimination must be exercised in all cases, and that no rule
LS to be blindly followed. The barrier that is most insurmountable to those
not benefited by the training of college work is an apparent inability to consider the pay received and services rendered in any other than an invariable

salary is not increased while the value of the work remains the same, and an
inflexibility results. This might serve as an illustration of the absurdity of
knowing no more mathematics than the rule of three.
There is a remarkable resemblance between the results obtained by the
methods of science and of business. The scientist commences with very simple
experiments and forms laws from the similarity of phenomena observed; these
laws are generalized and made into truths of wide application. The scientist is
not satisfied with the laws and truths verified by the experimental method; the
realm of experience must be transcended and sweeping theories of universal
cause and effect are given to the public. Likewise the business man starting
out in a very unpretentious way, at first engages in the grocery trade, or becomes a clerk in a banking house. After he has learned the axioms and first
problems of commerce and finance, he applies broader laws, and forms combinations of enterprises which formerly were conducted under various specific
principles. When it seems that he has reached a height of surpassing emi
Deuce, there is no ambition unfulfilled but the Titanic undertaking of a worldempire founded on commercial theories.
At the very first, the college man recognizes the scientific value of inductive reasoning. He sees that there are far reaching theories in business,
and he understands that their correct application can be attained only by the
inductive method. There is something ahead to make the first essays more
than mere mechanical effort, which should be classed with day labor. His conscientious labors are what might be called scientific endeavors to possess the
right of trying one's own view upon those interesting theories. The remuneration is, as it were, incidental,—a sort of testimonial of his success with the
early experiments, by which the doctrines of final cause can only be reached.
By thus mastering the work, and always striking higher, that rule of three
which was so stubborn to the one un versed in higher mathematics, is fitted in
with the other laws. Advancement comes with a rush. In a short while, the
college man has caught up with the non college man who started years ago.
In fact he is far ahead, for by virtue of his assimulation of the principles of his
work and with a broadened mind, he is more capable of filling higher positions.
To express it by an apt comparison, he has gained more momentum than the
other man who has reached the same point.
While it is no doubt very true that the college graduate is most prone to
place an unreal value upon himself, there is much that can be said in defense.
If this over-estimation is inherent, then it is not the college-course that has
created the evil, but a defect of the individuality of the man. On the other
hand, if the trouble is merely incidental to the distinction of a degree, the temporary aberration will wear away with the novelty of possessing an inscribed
sheepskin. At any rate, when the newly-created bachelor begins to be held
against the hard grindstone of the world, the rough points will soon be ground
off, and as this excessive self-appreciation is the most prominent, it will receive
the earliest attention.

HR management of the University Glee, Banjo and Mandolin Clubs has
selected Friday, February 27, as the date for the Baltimore concert, and
it is hoped that the student body and the friends of the University will
turn out in full force to show their appreciation of this prominent manifestation
of college spirit. In doing so, they should remember that this is the concert on
which the financial success of the clubs for the year is largely dependent, and
that a prosperous year means money for the athletic teams. Last year the
support given the clubs was commendable, and there, is no reason why the same
interest should not be shown this season.
To take another point of view,—nobody need be afraid of not getting the
worth of his money, for the program offered by the clubs this. Year is unusually
attractive. The men on all three of the clubs have worked faithfully since October; and, inspired by their smaller triumphs, will, no doubt, do their utmost
to make every one feel proud of the University's musical clubs on this occasion,
The Glee Club this year has had more material to choose from than in
former years, and the result is apparent. Many of the medical men have come
over, and most of them have trained their voices by experience on clubs of
other colleges. The leader, W. B. Carver, of the graduate department, has two
excellent medleys, besides the usual Hopkins songs and other glees.
The quartet this year has been selected with much care, and is composed of
Messrs. Coffin, Hall, Ford and Gilman. Mr. Gilman will sing solos. His
voice is better this year than ever, and his selections are admirable.
The Banjo Club is especially strong. "Charley" Marshall is leading
again, and he has managed to correct the few defects of last year's club. One
of the hits this year is the "Coon Quartet." In addition there is a popular
medley, and three rattling marches.
Edgeworth Smith is working hard in graduate history and politics, but it
is hoped that he will be prevailed upon to give a banjo solo.
The Mandolin Club, under the leadership of J. Wallace Bryan, '03, presents a large and varied collection of pieces,—a waltz by the author of
"Amoureuse," hits from "The Prince of Pilsen," "Mr. Pickwick," a march by
Victor Herbert, and Sousa's latest,—played recently before His Majesty of
England,--`'Imperial Edward."
One of the most attractive numbers will be the "Song of the Toreador,"
from Francis Wilson's opera, by the combined Glee and Mandolin Clubs.
Those who were at the concert of 1901 remember what a fine effect was produced by these two clubs when they accompanied the soloist in the "Princess
Chic" song. Then, too, a funny "stunt" man is promised, so that all tastes
will be suited. The only thing that is needed to make the concert an entire
success is a fine audience.
Last year nearly the whole Woman's College attended, and these girls are
expected this year. Surely, with this extra inducement, every one from the
Hopkins will be on hand! .

HE Honor System has now been discussed by all three classes, and a definite conclusion reached. Under present conditions perhaps the best way
out of the difficulty has been chosen. There was no protest against the
necessity of action being taken. All the classes were united in agreeing that the
little irregularities incident to examinations should he done away with by the
force of public opinion. In the future he will have to be a brazen man indeed
who will fly in the face of the emphatic convictions of the undergraduate body.
Soon after the opening of the first term next year, and in all future years no
doubt, men from the upper classes will explain to the new men what the sentiments of the undergraduates are on this subject, and after this exposition of
Hopkins ideals there can scarce be any fear of a transgression of the spirit or
the letter of the law.

N many respects the games held at the Armory last Saturday were eminently
unsatisfactory. As usual there seemed to be a desire on the part of those
interested to give Hopkins the worst of everything wherever there was the
slightest chance Yet it can hardly be said that much partiality was shown in
giving us the worst of it, as some others of the contestants did not get the best
of treatment at the hands of the officials. The opinion was expressed generally that never had there been a worse set of handicaps. It is customary in a

One of the rankest decisions handed out was the one disqualifying Freeze
In the quarter. He ran a pretty race and finished second. But one of the inspectors disqualified him for interfering with another man. The facts in the
case were that the other man stepped on Freeze's heel and was entirely to

excused himself by saying to one of our men, "You know that I did not know
that it was a Hopkins man, or I should never have done it." If he was honest
we cannot see why he should endeavor to disqualify anyone unfairly.
This same inspector, holding the position he does, as a trainer at one of the
preparatory. schools, he should never have been permitted to act as an official,
was seen to coach his men as they passed his turn; he was also miserably blind
when Randall was fouled by a Pennsylvania man. If he believes that these
methods are conclusive to clean and sportsmanlike athletics the NEWS-LETTH:R
begs to differ with him. A man who has played such an important part in college athletics should be above such petty devices which smack more of the professional sport, who will win at any cost, than of amateur athletics.
In the dash some interesting things were brought to light. In the afternoon when a man fell over his marks he was put back a foot, if he was put
back at all. Later this was excused by the starter declaring that he was ignorant of the rules. A man so ignorant should not be allowed to officiate. He
also let the men jump the gun; however, this is something which even the best
starters are not able to guard against all the time. Yet for this reason two good
Hopkins sprinters lost the opportunity of getting in the finals.
Handicap games are never satisfactory, and these were less so than any
held in Baltimore fot a long time. The public is not anxious to pay its money
so see a lot of third and fourth rate runners gallop around the track while the
good men are so hopelessly handicapped that they are never in the race. The
showing Hopkins made was as good as could be expected under the circumstances. All we can do is to' pull ourselves together and hope for better luck
next time.
This protest against the methods which characterized the games is made
not only on behalf of Hopkins, but on behalf of all the men who were victims

HILE it may seem presumptious for younger men to offer opinions about
a subject so much discussed by our elders, the suggestion prompts itself that the college graduate who has been in business only a few years
will be more respected as a judge, when it is remembered that he is closer to the
two conditions of life, and is more susceptible.
As a brief prelude, a few words about the length of an ideal college course
seem applicable. The many advocates of college training for men tell that this
incipient period of life is most in need of scientific care, for it is the chrystalizing stage,—a time when the hardening cast must be taken from the mould. Entering into business means undertaking a life pursuit, and a decision cannot be
summarily dismissed. While it is true that most men commencing business
are not permitted by circumstances to choose their exact branch, it must be admitted that a man who knows his own propensities, can by dint of determination fulfill his ambition at a later time. So that without venturing an opinion
as to the exact number of years to be spent in college, it is safe to say that the
cast must be formed, and tempered to the atmosphere before being exposed to
the elements.
.
Aside from the general polish and completeness that a college course gives
to all, the most refreshing observance that one makes of college men in business
IS the seriousness with which they view their life occupation. In the classes
of undergraduate years, in the self imposed work on college periodicals and in
athletics, it has been discovered that system and responsibility are essential to
all successes, and the ones who attain proficiency, or even mediocrity in any of
the college associations necessarily absorb most of the serious and solid elements of life.
The time taken up, and the exaggerated value that bachelors of art are apt
to set upon themselves, are the chief arguments advanced against a college degree for business men. In most cases, however, the time lost means only a
temporary delay, and the first objection seems very easily overcome. Of course,
there are many positions from which promotion can only be had in routine
order. In answer to this, it must be said that college men are brain-workers
and not machines, and that wherever there is a chance to excel and to be
recognized, the college man will receive and accept business principles as such.
He knows that discrimination must be exercised in all cases, and that no rule
LS to be blindly followed. The barrier that is most insurmountable to those
not benefited by the training of college work is an apparent inability to consider the pay received and services rendered in any other than an invariable

There is a remarkable resemblance between the results obtained by the
methods of science and of business. The scientist commences with very simple
experiments and forms laws from the similarity of phenomena observed; these
laws are generalized and made into truths of wide application. The scientist is
not satisfied with the laws and truths verified by the experimental method; the
realm of experience must be transcended and sweeping theories of universal
cause and effect are given to the public. Likewise the business man starting
out in a very unpretentious way, at first engages in the grocery trade, or becomes a clerk in a banking house. After he has learned the axioms and first
problems of commerce and finance, he applies broader laws, and forms combinations of enterprises which formerly were conducted under various specific
principles. When it seems that he has reached a height of surpassing emi
Deuce, there is no ambition unfulfilled but the Titanic undertaking of a worldempire founded on commercial theories.
At the very first, the college man recognizes the scientific value of inductive reasoning. He sees that there are far reaching theories in business,
and he understands that their correct application can be attained only by the
inductive method. There is something ahead to make the first essays more
than mere mechanical effort, which should be classed with day labor. His conscientious labors are what might be called scientific endeavors to possess the
right of trying one's own view upon those interesting theories. The remuneration is, as it were, incidental,—a sort of testimonial of his success with the
early experiments, by which the doctrines of final cause can only be reached.
By thus mastering the work, and always striking higher, that rule of three
which was so stubborn to the one un versed in higher mathematics, is fitted in
with the other laws. Advancement comes with a rush. In a short while, the
college man has caught up with the non college man who started years ago.
In fact he is far ahead, for by virtue of his assimulation of the principles of his
work and with a broadened mind, he is more capable of filling higher positions.
To express it by an apt comparison, he has gained more momentum than the
other man who has reached the same point.
While it is no doubt very true that the college graduate is most prone to
place an unreal value upon himself, there is much that can be said in defense.
If this over-estimation is inherent, then it is not the college-course that has
created the evil, but a defect of the individuality of the man. On the other
hand, if the trouble is merely incidental to the distinction of a degree, the temporary aberration will wear away with the novelty of possessing an inscribed
sheepskin. At any rate, when the newly-created bachelor begins to be held
against the hard grindstone of the world, the rough points will soon be ground
off, and as this excessive self-appreciation is the most prominent, it will receive
the earliest attention.

BASE BALL FOR 1903.
N answer to the various inquiries that have been made from time to time, the
statement may now be accepted as authoritative that Hopkins will have a
base ball team in the field this season Present prospects are very encouraging. Ever since the unfavorable action of the Athletic Board in this direction
some weeks ago, the question of a team "to be or not to be," has been more or
less discussed, but only in a vague, 'indefinite sort of way, except by those
especially interested in the team's success. These, remembering the hard, but
futile fight for recognition last year, were in no way discouraged,—although
disappointed,—by the unfavorable verdict of the Board this year, have been,
with characteristic perseverance and "stick-at-it-ness," quietly at work formulating plans for the organization of a successful, self supporting team.
The spirit shown by the members of recent base ball teams is worthy of the
highest commendation, and cannot but help elevate athletics in general at our
institution No man participates from any sense of duty, as is sometimes
unfortunately, but undeniably, the case in other branches of athletics; but each
is actuated purely and solely by his love for the game. Since no athletic honors—the "reward of personal ability"—are offered in this line as an incentive
